abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Northeast Emergency
            Irrigated Agriculture Project for Sri Lanka were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was un-evaluable, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            lending for land-based assets in a protracted conflict
            affected situation, characterized by massive displacement,
            and should be sequenced within a broader social development
            framework that balances individual needs with equity aims.
            The term ‘post-conflict’ should be used sparingly in the
            absence of a negotiated peace agreement and World Bank
            projects should accordingly exercise caution in project
            design in situations where conflict may re-emerge. There is
            a tension between responding to the immediate needs of
            conflict affected populations and the use of a community
            driven development model to respond to these needs in fluid
            or highly mobile environments. Participatory development is
            a process that should be nurtured and supported throughout
            all stages of a project cycle.
